fields.value: Data of Metabolic requirements and diet of a common Indo-Pacific mangrove crab Metopograpsus frontalis

dsDescriptionValue.value: This dataset represents all the data collected in Moreton Bay from 2016 to 2017 as part of the research project and manuscript article: Metabolic requirements and diet of a common Indo-Pacific mangrove crab Metopograpsus frontalis under consideration in Journal of Marine Science and Engineering. This dataset contains 4 different files, each related to the 4 sections of the results. Calorimetry experiments.xlsx refers to the data collected and used for the caloric content of two common food items of M.frontalis. Handling time results.xlsx refers to the time M.frontalis crabs took to consume either algae or oysters samples. Metabolism experiments resutls.xlsx refers to teh data from te oyxgen consumption experiments. Time activity budgets .xlsx refers to the field data collected in Moreton Bay.

files.description: The caloric content of two key food items (C. nipae and S. cucullata) were obtained,200 g of C. nipae and 140 g of oyster flesh (84 S. cucullata oysters) were hand collected from Polka Point, North Stradbroke Island at low tide.From each sample, four 0.2 g subsamples were combusted, resulting in four repeated measurements for each food item sample
files.label: Calorimetry experiments.tab

dataFile.description: The caloric content of two key food items (C. nipae and S. cucullata) were obtained,200 g of C. nipae and 140 g of oyster flesh (84 S. cucullata oysters) were hand collected from Polka Point, North Stradbroke Island at low tide.From each sample, four 0.2 g subsamples were combusted, resulting in four repeated measurements for each food item sample

files.description: Crabs were acclimated for 10 min after which an initial oxygen value recorded when the crabs first began to handle the food item. For the protein diet group, a partially opened S. cucullata oyster (approximately 2 cm long and 1.5 g of oyster flesh) was inserted into the container and the time taken to completely open and consume a piece of the oyster flesh was recorded as the handling time (Figure 2d). For the plant diet group, the container had a meal of C. nipae (0.2 g) attached to a mesh (0.25 x 0.25 cm) and the mesh glued to a small and partially flat rock (~0.27 x 0.27 cm) with two drops of transparent silicone sealant liquid from RS Pro (Figure 2c). This setup allowed for accurate measurement of crab energy consumption while handling algae [30]. Handling time was recorded with a Accusplit Pro Survivor Stopwatch (± 0.1 s) from when the crab began to graze on the algae, to when it was placed into the buccal cavity.
files.label: Handling_time_results.tab

dataFile.description: Crabs were acclimated for 10 min after which an initial oxygen value recorded when the crabs first began to handle the food item. For the protein diet group, a partially opened S. cucullata oyster (approximately 2 cm long and 1.5 g of oyster flesh) was inserted into the container and the time taken to completely open and consume a piece of the oyster flesh was recorded as the handling time (Figure 2d). For the plant diet group, the container had a meal of C. nipae (0.2 g) attached to a mesh (0.25 x 0.25 cm) and the mesh glued to a small and partially flat rock (~0.27 x 0.27 cm) with two drops of transparent silicone sealant liquid from RS Pro (Figure 2c). This setup allowed for accurate measurement of crab energy consumption while handling algae [30]. Handling time was recorded with a Accusplit Pro Survivor Stopwatch (± 0.1 s) from when the crab began to graze on the algae, to when it was placed into the buccal cavity.

files.description: Crabs were transferred to a 0.25 L plastic air-tight oblong container with an oxygen sensor spot glued to it and 0.24 L of seawater. Each crab was only utilised once. An oxygen meter measured the oxygen consumption of the crabs while (a) resting (n= 45), (b) under stress (n= 45), (c) feeding algae (n= 44), and (d) feeding oysters (n= 45). Measurements were taken every minute for 20 min and a metabolic rate was calculated for each individual
files.label: Metabolism experiments results.tab

dataFile.description: Crabs were transferred to a 0.25 L plastic air-tight oblong container with an oxygen sensor spot glued to it and 0.24 L of seawater. Each crab was only utilised once. An oxygen meter measured the oxygen consumption of the crabs while (a) resting (n= 45), (b) under stress (n= 45), (c) feeding algae (n= 44), and (d) feeding oysters (n= 45). Measurements were taken every minute for 20 min and a metabolic rate was calculated for each individual

files.description: Observation of crabs occurred at all the study sites (n =24 on each site) for one hour during the austral summer season (November – February). A 20 m transect was placed parallel to the shore and six 1 m2 quadrats were laid down on the seaward side of the transect. When the six quadrats were laid down, the observer stood 5 m away from the quadrats and chose one crab on each quadrat with distinctive morphological features such as size, distinctive white spots on the carapace or strong purple colouration of the chelae, which allowed for easier observations. The observer recorded the duration of four main activities
files.label: Time_activity_budgets.tab
